title: Best places to cycle in the French Pyrenees
content:
Cyclist
Best places to cycle in the French Pyrenees

The Pyrenees mountains are home to some of cycling’s most famous climbs that have played host to countless Tour de France battles. There are also a host of lesser known climbs that are equally beautiful and rewarding, but without the crowds.

While the Tour has crossed the Col du Tourmalet over 80 times, it’s not the highest road in the Pyrenees. Aided by local experts, Cyclist has ridden the higher Lac de Cap-de-Long, and that’s just the start of the long list of hidden gems.

Having been travelling the world in search of the most beautiful and challenging places to ride bikes since 2012, we’ve seen the best the Pyrenees has to offer, so we’ve put together our findings to help you filter through the noise and plan your next trip.

We’ve also got information on how to get there and the main gateways to the mountains.

Map of French Pyrenees’ best cycling climbs

The Pyrenees stretch across the entire France/Spain border at more than 490km in length. That means there’s a heck of a lot of cycling to be discovered both on- and off-road, so with that in mind we’ve grouped our list into départments to make it easier to figure out geographically.

We’ve ridden every one of these climbs as part of either our monthly Big Rides or our Classic Climbs series, so we’re able to give you the inside scoop of how far and how hard, where to stay and how to get there for each of them.

Best places to cycle in the French Pyrenees

Ariège

Just south of Toulouse is the Arièges départment, which is home to France’s border with Andorra and part of the border with Spain’s Catalonia region. On the French side it’s sandwiched between Haute-Garonne and Pyrénées-Orientales to the west and east respectively.

Plateau de Beille

A ski resort in winter, it has featured six times as a summit finish in the Tour de France with a mixed bag of winners, most recently Joaquím Rodriguez.

  • Length: 15.8km
  • Gradient: 7.9% average, 11% maximum
  • Where: Starting from Les Cabannes, half an hour up the road from Foix or Ax-les-Thermes.
  • How: Just over an hour’s drive from Toulouse, about the same to the small (but international) airport at Carcassonne, and an hour more from Béziers.

In pro cycling:

  • Plateau de Beille’s Tour de France history
  • Tour de France history: Pantani goes from hero to legend
  • Alberto Contador: Hero or villain?

Port de Pailhères

Always the bridesmaid, but far from just a warm-up, Port de Pailhères has featured five times in the Tour de France, never as a summit finish – normally coming before Ax 3 Domaines and once before Plateau de Beille – but once as the Souvenir Henri Desgrange (the highest summit of each year’s Tour) with the top just sneaking over 2,000m of altitude.

  • Length: 10.6km (from Mijanès); 18.6km (from Ax-les-Thermes)
  • Gradient: 8.2% average, 10.2% max (from Mijanès); 6.9% average, 10.4% max (from Ax-les-Thermes)
  • Where: Starting either from Mijanès on the east side or Ax-les-Thermes on the west, the peak sits on Ariège’s northern border with the Aude départment, which is why it’s also known as Col de Pailhères (although both sides of the climb stay in Ariège).
  • How: From Toulouse, it’s approximately 1h 35min by car to Ax-les-Thermes and 2h 20min to Mijanès, Carcassonne to Mijanès is 1h 45min and 1h 50min to Ax-les-Thermes, Béziers is about 2h 30min away.

In pro cycling:

  • The last time the Tour visited Port de Pailhères was 2013 when Chris Froome won Stage 8 by 51 seconds. Port de Pailhères was the penultimate climb with Nairo Quintana cresting its summit first.

Route suggestions:

  • Port de Pailhères climb on Komoot

Haute-Garonne

Haute-Garonne doesn’t share much of a border with Spain as its Pyrenean area is quite narrow, with the bulk of the départment further north including Toulouse and the surrounding area. However it’s home to a couple of big time climbs.

Col de Peyresourde

One of the Tour de France classics visited over 50 times but never as a summit finish, it’s wide and expansive. Ride on to the Peyragudes altiport at the top for extra climbing.

  • Length: 15.3km (from Bagnères-de-Luchon); 8.3km (from Armenteule)
  • Gradient: 6.1% average, 9% max (from Bagnères-de-Luchon); 7.6% average, 9.5% max (from Armenteule)
  • Where: The Col de Peyresourde bridges riders between Haute-Garonne and Hautes-Pyrénées, with the Bagnères-de-Luchon start in the former and Armenteule in the latter.
  • How: From the Tarbes-Lourdes-Pyrénées airport, it’s just over an hour’s drive to either starting point, or it’s about 40 minutes extra from Toulouse airport. It’s just under two hours to drive from Pau. All three have train stations.

Superbagnères

The scene of some of the Tour de France’s greatest battles, it hasn’t been used by the Tour since 1989 but remains a great climb to ride.

  • Length: 18.5km
  • Gradient: 6.3% average, 12% max
  • Where: Starts from Bagnères-de-Luchon
  • How: The nearest airport is Tarbes-Lourdes-Pyrénées, which is just over an hour by car to Bagnères-de-Luchon, Toulouse and Pau airports are about 40 minutes further northeast and northwest respectively. Lourdes, Toulouse and Pau also have train stations too.

In pro cycling:

  • The last time Superbagnères featured at the Tour de France was in 1989 when Pippa York (then Robert Millar) won the stage and Laurent Fignon took over the yellow jersey from Greg LeMond.
  • No slowing down: Greg LeMond profile

Route suggestions:

  • Tour de France climbs: Superbagnères

Hautes-Pyrénées

Although it looks like there might not be much along the mountain range in the Hautes-Pyrénées, it soon becomes clear where it gets its name. Most of the biggest and best climbs are here.

Cirque de Troumouse

A stunning hidden gem that the Tour de France has never visited, so there’s less motorised and pedal-powered traffic than on other climbs.

  • Length: 28km
  • Gradient: 5%
  • Where: Starts from Luz-Saint-Saveur, the summit is at the border with Spain.
  • How: Luz-Saint-Saveur is only a 45 minute drive from Tarbes-Lourdes-Pyrenees airport and half an hour more from Pau airport or train station. It’s only half an hour from Lourdes train station.

In pro cycling:

  • Nothing.

Route suggestions:

  • The old one-two: Pyrenees Big Ride

Col d’Aspin

A Tour de France legend but always a bridesmaid, it’s tougher than it looks to ride and includes long 8% stretches.

  • Length: 12.8km (from Sainte-Marie de Campan); 12km (from Arreau)
  • Gradient: 5% average, 9% max (from Sainte-Marie de Campan); 6.5% average, 10% max (from Arreau).
  • Where: The climb takes riders between the valleys of the Adour and Neste rivers, with Sainte-Marie in the former to the northwest of the summit and Arreau in the southeast and Neste.
  • How: It’s only a 45 minute drive from Lourdes to Saint-Marie de Campan and an extra ten to Arreau. Pau is also within reach, about 1h 20min away, and Toulouse is 1h 45min(ish).

In pro cycling:

  • Featured in both men’s and women’s Tour de France in 2023.
  • Tour de France 2022 gallery: Pogačar says bye and hi to teammates as he track sprints to Stage 17 victory
  • Tour de France history: Switzerland’s short-lived success

  • The Circle of Death: France Big Ride

  • Marmotte Granfondo Pyrenees sportive: Second helping

Col de Tentes

The longest climb in the Pyrenees and higher than the Tourmalet, but it will probably never feature in the Tour de France.

  • Length: 30km
  • Gradient: 5% average, 12% max
  • Where: Starts frm Luz-Saint-Saveur, finishes on Spanish border.
  • How: Luz-Saint-Saveur is only a 45 minute drive from Tarbes-Lourdes-Pyrenees airport and half an hour more from Pau airport or train station. It’s only half an hour from Lourdes train station.

In pro cycling:

  • Nothing.

Route suggestions:

  • The old one-two: Pyrenees Big Ride

Col du Soulor

A bridesmaid climb to the Aubisque and part of the gruelling Circle of Death, the ascent from Arthez-d’Asson is the one used more frequently in the Tour.

  • Length: 22km (from Arthez d’Asson); 19.5km (from Argelès-Gazost)
  • Gradient: 4.9% average, 11% max (from Arthez d’Asson); 5.2% average, 10% max (from Argelès-Gazost)
  • Where: Crosses between Pyrénées-Atlantiques and Hautes-Pyrenees, Arthez-d’Asson route, which is in the former, straddles the border for a while.
  • How: It’s about 45 minutes by car from Pau and Lourdes and just over two hours from Toulouse to Arthez d’Asson, while it’s half an hour from Pau, an hour from Lourdes and two hours from Toulouse to Argèles-Gazost.

In pro cycling:

  • Featured in the Tour on many occasions as part of the infamous ‘Circle of Death’ and alongside with Col d’Aubisque.
  • Tour de France 2019: Thomas loses time to Alaphilippe as Pinot wins Stage 14 on the Tourmalet

Route suggestions:

  • Classic climb: Col du Soulor, the hidden Pyrenean gem
  • The Circle of Death: France Big Ride

Col du Tourmalet

The classic Pyrenean climb, and steeped in Tour history. There’s more beyond the top too if you venture off-road to Pic du Midi de Bigorre.

  • Length: 19km (from Luz-Saint-Saveur); 17.1km (from Sainte-Marie de Campan)
  • Gradient: 7.4% average, 12% max (from Luz-Saint-Saveur); 7.4% average, 11% max (Sainte-Marie de Campan)
  • Where: Start from either Luz-Saint-Saveur in the southwest or Sainte-Marie de Campan in the northeast, the Tour tackles both ways up.
  • How: Both Luz-Saint-Saveur and Sainte-Marie de Campan are about a 45 minute drive from Tarbes-Lourdes-Pyrenees airport and half an hour more from Pau airport or train station. Toulouse is 1h 45min(ish).

Hautacam

A big climb featured six times at the Tour de France, though its legend is dominated by dopers.

  • Length: 17.3km
  • Gradient: 6.8% average, 10% max
  • Where: Starts in Argelès-Gazost, just down the road from Lourdes.
  • How: Argelès-Gazost is only 15 minutes by car from Lourdes and 30 from the airport. It’s about an hour from Pau and two from Toulouse.

In pro cycling:

  • Gallery: Jonas Vingegaard shows pure class on final mountain stage to all but secure 2022 Tour de France victory

Route suggestions:

  • Tour de France climb: Hautacam

Hourquette d’Ancizan

First featured in the Tour in 2011, it’s already racked up five appearances, slotting in the middle of some heavy mountain stages.

  • Length: 22.6km (from Campan); 10.3km (from Ancizan)
  • Gradient: 4% average, 11% max (from Campan); 7.8% average, 12% max (from Ancizan)
  • Where: Just round the corner from the Tourmalet, starting in Campan in the north and Ancizan in the south.
  • How: It’s about 30 minutes from Lourdes, an hour from Pau and two from Toulouse to Campan, and about an hour from Lourdes, a further half an hour from Pau and just under two hours from Toulouse to Ancizan.

In pro cycling:

  • Tour de France 2019: Simon Yates wins Stage 12 from break as GC holds station

Route suggestions:

  • The long haul: Lac de Cap-de-Long Big Ride

Lac de Cap-de-Long

One of the greatest French climbs never to have featured in the Tour.

  • Length: 22.7km
  • Gradient: 5.9% average, 11.8% max
  • Where: Starts from Saint-Lary-Soulan, heads west to the aforementioned lake.
  • How: Saint-Lary-Soulan is about an hour from Lourdes, just under two from Pau and about two from Toulouse.

In pro cycling:

  • Nothing.

Route suggestions:

  • The long haul: Lac de Cap-de-Long Big Ride

Port de Balès

Scene of one of the Tour’s most notorious incidents and a vicious climb to ride.

  • Length: 18.9km (from Mauléon-Barousse); 19.7km (from Bagnères-de-Luchon)
  • Gradient: 6.3% average, 13% max (from Mauléon-Barousse); 5.7% average, 13.3% max (from Bagnères-de-Luchon)
  • Where: Crosses the Hautes-Pyrénées and Haute-Garonne border, not far from Spain.
  • How: To Mauléon-Barousse, it’s a one hour drive from Lourdes and an hour and a half from both Pau and Toulouse. Bagnères-de-Luchon is just over an hour to Lourdes and just under two hours from Pau and Toulouse.

In pro cycling:

  • Tour de France history: ‘Chaingate’ rocks the Tour in 2010
  • Romain Bardet wins Tour de France stage 12, Aru takes yellow

Route suggestions:

  • Cycling’s best climbs: Port de Balès

Pyrénées-Atlantiques

The most western Pyrenean départment catches some fantastic climbs as the range dips down towards the coast and the Basque Country, and features famous Tour de France town Pau.

Col d’Arnostéguy

Narrow, steep road up to the Spanish border that’s untouched by the Tour.

  • Length: 25.1km (west); 17.9km (north); 26.1km (east)
  • Gradient: 4.3% average, 15% max (west); 6% average, 17.9% max (north); 4.1% average, 12.2% max (east)
  • Where: All three ways up start from Saint-Jean-Pied-de-Port, not far from the west coast.
  • How: To Saint-Jean-Pied-de-Port it’s an hour by car from Biarritz, an hour and a half from San Sebastian or Pau and two hours from Lourdes.

In pro cycling:

  • Nothing.

Route suggestions:

  • Bordering on the insane: West Pyrenees Big Ride

Col d’Aubisque

One of the Tour’s most used climbs. Another part of the famous Circle of Death, with stunning views.

  • Length: 16.6km (from Laruns); 30.1km (from Argèles-Gazost)
  • Gradient: 7.2% average, 10% max (from Laruns); 4.1% average, 9% max (from Argèles-Gazost)
  • Where: Crosses the Pyrénées-Atlantiques and Hautes-Pyrénées border
  • How: Laruns is under an hour from Pau, about an hour from Lourdes and two hours from Biarritz. Argelès-Gazost is only 15 minutes by car from Lourdes and 30 from the airport. It’s about an hour from Pau and two from Toulouse.

  • The Circle of Death: France Big Ride

Col de Bagargui

The Col de Bagargui, also known as Col Bagargiak, has featured in the Tour three times, most notably when Tyler Hamilton won his only stage with a big solo breakaway in 2003.

  • Length: 21.2km (from Larrau); 29.5km (from Esterençuby)
  • Gradient: 4.8% average, 15.5% max (from Larrau); 3.7% average, 12.8% max (from Esterençuby)
  • Where: Runs parallel to the Spanish border between Larrau and Esterençuby.
  • How: To either starting point it’s about an hour by car from Biarritz, an hour and a half from San Sebastian or Pau and two hours from Lourdes.

In pro cycling:

  • No more secrets: Tyler Hamilton profile

Route suggestions:

  • Bordering on the insane: West Pyrenees Big Ride

Port de Larrau

With an ascent either side of the border, it’s also called the Puerto de Larrau, it’s featured twice in the Tour in 1996 and 2007, going opposite ways up.

  • Length: 27.8km (from Tardets-Sorholus); 19.3km (from Ochagavía)
  • Gradient: 4.8% average, 14% max (from Tardets-Sorholus); 4.3% average, 9% max (from Ochagavía)
  • Where: Crossing over the Spanish border as the mountains start to calm down towards the coast.
  • How: Tardets-Sorholus is about an hour from Pau, an hour and a half from Lourdes and Biarritz and about two hours from San Sebastian. It’s two hours from San Sebastian to Ochagavía on the Spanish side too. Pamplona, the closest big town, is an hour away.

In pro cycling:

  • Miguel Induraín’s final Tour de France climb in 1996, ending his run of five straight yellow jersey wins.

Route suggestions:

  • Bordering on the insane: West Pyrenees Big Ride

Pyrénées Orientales

Its proximity to the coast means the climbs begin to thin out in the Pyrénées Orientales, however you also get the sea and lovely coastal towns like Collioure to stay in.

Col de Jau

  • Length: 13.4km (from Sainte-Colombe-sur-Guette); 13.6km (from Mosset)
  • Gradient: 6.7% average, 9.8% max (from Saint-Colombe-sur-Guette); 5.9% average, 8% max (from Mosset)
  • Where: Crosses the border between the Aude and Pyrénées-Orientales départements.
  • How: It’s an hour from Perpignan to Mosset and an hour and a half from Narbonne. It’s just over an hour from Perpignan to Saint-Colombe-sur-Guette, just under two hours from Narbonne and just over two from Toulouse.

In pro cycling:

  • Only featured three times in the Tour, most recently in 2001.

Route suggestions:

  • Orientales Express: Pyrenees Big Ride

Travelling to the French Pyrenees

Toulouse

The nearest major centre to the big central Pyrenean climbs is Toulouse. As a major city and commercial centre for southern France, it’s well served with flights from the UK

  • Book flights from London to Toulouse with Expedia

Barcelona

Most of the action is in the central Pyrenees, but if you want to head to some of the eastern Pyrenean climbs such as the Port de Pailhères, Barcelona is an alternative.

  • Book flights from London to Barcelona with British Airways

Lourdes

An option that will get you closer to the big climbs in the Hautes-Pyrénées, Lourdes is served by flights from the UK for those seeking pilgrimage, but is equally good for riders.

  • Book flights from London to Lourdes with TravelSupermarket

Biarritz

Biarritz is a good jumping off point for the far western mountains. It’s around a one hour drive to the mountains, making for a shorter transfer than from Toulouse or Barcelona. 

  • Book flights from London to Biarritz with LastMinute.com

Other options

You can also get planes or trains to (from west to east): San Sebastian, Pau, Carcassonne and Perpignan.

Where to stay

Pau is the classic starting point for many Tour stages in the Pyrenees and as the largest town in the area is a good base if you want to hit the most famous climbs. Other options include Lourdes of pilgrimage fame and, for the eastern ranges, Andorra or Perpignan.

As with the Alps, ski resorts provide plenty of accommodation and amenities that, out of the ski season, may not be expensive, although they’ll be at the top of a climb to get you home at the end of a day already spent climbing.

  • Check out accommodation in the Pyrenees with Booking.com
